Name: Design Corporal
Comment:
Hello teacher!
 I have an electronics question from the Arduino nano 33 ble board.  feeding it with 12v directly on the VIN can I energize a tape with two rgb leds on the 5v output and a touch sensor on the 3.3v output?

Name: Robocraze
Comment: No, please dont do that. The Nano 33 BLE can step down 5V to 3.3V. It does not support stepping down 12V to 3.3V. The BLE exclusively operates on 3.3V. If you would like to connect devices with higher voltage rating, you can give the give the 12V power exclusively to the device and just tie the GNDs of the Nano and the device together

Name: Naveen Kumar
Comment: Updating edge firmware  will cause any issue? like old firmware features works properly?

Name: Robocraze
Comment: Edge Impulse firmware is just a precompiled program for the board. To use EI, you will need the EI firmware to be uploaded on the board. You can still use the microcontroller for normal uses by just uploading another program through Arduino IDE.

Name: Jon Pinkley
Comment: What happens if someone just holds down all 4 buttons continuously?

Name: Robocraze
Comment: In that case, it would indeed consider it as a button press and you could beat the game. In order to fix this, you can use button states and only on a rising edge, set the button_pressed variable. So you can use last state and current state and check if last state is LOW and current state is HIGH, only then consider a button press.

Name: Vlad Dobritoiu
Comment: what's a good method to use interrupts with more than one button?

Name: Shiv Capoor
Comment: I would say the easiest with few number of buttons would be to attach an interrupt to each button. The callback function  has the gpio argument which would tell you the gpio on which the interrupt came. If you have many buttons, you would need to use a parallel in serial out shift register to multiplex all the buttons. However this is a far more complicated solution.

Name: pdxfunk
Comment: Thanks for this! Question: What is the *t all about  in the callback? This is a deference of pointer t right? But I don't see where "t" shows up anywhere else.

Name: Shiv Capoor
Comment:
Hi,

The *t that you see in the callback function is a pointer to the timer object that is responsible for calling the callback function. As you have rightly observed, the * operator is the dereference operator, however in the context of a function parameter, this indicates a pointer to the timer corresponding to the call to the callback function. This provides you access to the timer object inside the callback function in case you need it. One example i can think of would be to maybe disable the timer or to change its parameters etc. it is not used inside the callback function since the operation being performed does not require any modifications to the original timer object. Hope this answers your question.

Name: Harsh Varagiya
Comment: How to find which channel (PWM_CHAN_A) belongs to which gpio pin ?

Name: Robocraze
Comment:
Hi Harsh,
You can use the function pwm_gpio_to_channel to get the channel connected to the gpio. The signature of this function is:
static uint pwm_gpio_to_channel (uint gpio)
To read more about the function, please check the SDK documentation section 4.1.18.3.13. Link to the SDK documentation is given below:
https://datasheets.raspberrypi.org/pico/raspberry-pi-pico-c-sdk.pdf

Name: Kevin McDonald
Comment: I am attempting to duplicate this project for learning purposes, but I am a bit confused about 1 thing. I am able to get the code up and running and connected to the nrf connect app. However in the values field I only receive the hex value never the actual string. What do you think causes this? (I am using an iPhone)

Name: Robocraze
Comment: You can try manually converting the hex values to string to check if the values you are receiving is indeed correct. If it is correct, then the issue is with the nRF app settings as its not doing the conversion process due to probably some incorrect settings on the app

Comment: Hi, nice vidio, but i want to ask you how about send over ble sense and ble device as peripheral and central. how can send float data?

Name: jeff
Comment: I am having trouble believing that this is a proper BLE solution since your USB cable remained connected to your computer the whole time. Your nRF Connect showed the sensor data which was the same as that from the serial monitor. I need the Arduino to connect to the nRF Connect but without being attached to the computer, and the signal does not advertise in this case. I'm trying to discover a fix for this, but I would appreciate any ideas from this community. Thanks

Name: Robocraze
Comment:
The nano is connected to the computer solely for power purposes. You can connect the same setup directly to the power adaptor and achieve the same results.
nRF data shows the same serial because the same device sends both to serial and Bluetooth. It was shown for verification.

Congratulations on the presentation/class!
I have a doubt!
If I make a voice command for example "STOP" or "PLAY" can any voice activate or just mine?

Name: Robocraze
